div.p: Greetings. I recently received your letters, to which I have nothing to respond, nor do I have much time to write now, as I am very busy. What I had, I wrote to our Gwalther; he will share it with you.

I can hardly persuade myself that a council in Konstanz will take place; it did not proceed in Trient, how would it proceed or succeed here? They are driven by a spirit of confusion, so that they do not know where they should turn; they wish to suppress the cause of truth, but they cannot and will not be able to, by the grace of the Lord, who powerfully resists their efforts.
We have nothing yet from France.
I am now sending Musculus's "Loci" through this person; the printer thought he would send it to you in his name. Since they did not do this, he is sending you a copy himself.
Bern, September 2, 1560. May all of yours be well.
To the most distinguished man, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, the most faithful pastor of the ZÃ¼rich church, his most esteemed lord and dearest compatriot.
